content: How can I help you today?

I'm not really sure how to start. Things have been really hard at home lately, and my wife thought coming here might help. Honestly, I’m skeptical this will do anything, but I’m trying to keep an open mind, I guess.

It sounds like you’re going through a tough time, and it’s commendable that you’re willing to give this a try, even though you’re feeling uncertain. What’s been happening at home that’s made things difficult for you?

Well, it’s mostly about my son. He’s been having behavioral issues, and my wife and I just can’t seem to figure out how to help him. It’s causing so much stress between us, and it feels like it's tearing our family apart.

That sounds incredibly challenging, and it’s understandable that you’d be feeling the weight of the stress on your family. It also shows how much you care about your son and your family that you’re working hard to figure this out. What do you think has been the hardest part for you in all of this?

I think it's just the feeling of helplessness...like no matter what I do, nothing seems to get better. My son is struggling, my wife and I are arguing more, and it feels like I'm losing the connection with my daughter too because all the focus is on him. I just don’t know how to hold everything together anymore.

Feeling helpless when you’re trying so hard to make things better can be overwhelming, especially when it feels like everything is pulling apart. The effort you're putting into your family shows how deeply you care, even when it feels like it’s not working the way you hope. What are some ways you've tried to handle things so far?

We’ve tried talking to him, setting boundaries, being more lenient, being stricter—nothing seems to really get through to him. My wife and I have different ideas about what might help, and that just leads to more arguments. I feel like I've run out of ideas, and I don’t even know what would work anymore.

It sounds like you and your wife have been trying so many different approaches to help your son, but the disagreements and lack of progress are leaving you both frustrated and unsure of what to do next. It’s clear that you’ve been putting a lot of thought and effort into this—it’s a tough position to be in when the answers aren’t coming easily. What do you think could make a difference, even if you’re not sure how to achieve it yet?
I honestly don’t know anymore. I guess we need some kind of outside help, but I’m not sure what that even looks like or if it would really make a difference. I feel drained and just...lost.

It sounds like you’ve been carrying a heavy emotional and mental load, and it’s exhausting not knowing the way forward. Recognizing that outside help might be needed shows strength and a willingness to explore solutions—it’s not easy to reach that point, especially when you’re feeling drained. What kind of support or help do you think might feel manageable for you and your family right now?

I’m not really sure. Maybe someone who could help us figure out what’s going on with my son, or even just give me and my wife some guidance on how to approach this without being at odds all the time. I still feel skeptical, though, like what if even that doesn’t help? It’s hard to imagine things improving.

It makes sense to have doubts when things have felt so stuck for such a long time. Seeking support is a big step, and it can be scary to hope for change when you’re not sure it’s possible. At the same time, looking for guidance together could help ease some of the tension between you and your wife while creating a clearer path forward for your son. What do you think would help ease some of the skepticism?

I think if I could see some real progress or feel like we’re all on the same page—me, my wife, and whoever might help us—it might make a difference. It’s just hard to imagine trusting that someone else will have the answers when we’ve felt so stuck. But deep down, I do want things to get better. I just don’t know where to start.

Wanting things to get better, even when you’re feeling stuck, shows how deeply you care about your family and their well-being. Building trust and being on the same page sounds really important to you—and finding someone to guide you in small, manageable steps could be a way to start reconnecting and making progress. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about before we explore more specific ways to move forward?
I think I am okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
